newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT - Crude has solid base, needs gasoline lead.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Crude has solid base, needs gasoline lead.

text.p: NEARBY MONTH CLOSE * SUPPORT * RESIST * RSI-14 * MA-10 * MA-20

* Brent's inability to break down has left good support in a band around the $19.95-$20.10 range and with a little help from gasoline prices could continue to track higher. * Gas oil's $173 to $176.50 gap-up from last Friday to Monday remains supportively intact providing a solid base to move higher.

More consolidation looks likely on Brent crude oil futures, dealers and chartists said. This week's period of chart congestion above $20 after last Friday's rally looks likely to have set new higher levels of support giving a solid base to move up from.
However, futures brokers said crude will look increasingly to NYMEX gasoline for a lead higher as Memorial Day in the U.S. on Monday traditionally marks the start of the gasoline season.
"It's gasoline season. If gas is going to lead anything, this is the time," said Tom Bentz, analyst at High Yield Analytics in New Yorks.
NYMEX ACCESS trade saw June unleaded gasoline 0.23 cents a gallon lower at around $66.70.
July Brent was quoted at $20.08/15 a barrel on SIMEX, slightly off from the London close of $20.18. NYMEX crude on ACCESS was last done at $21.78 off eight cents from the close.

Analysts said on Brent the bulls appeared to be winning the day with the market's inability to break down leaving good support in a band around the $19.95-$20.10 range and with a little help from gasoline prices could continue to track higher.
They saw the next upside target as $21.35, Thursday's high, after which the contract high of $21.90 will come into focus.

Fenella Graham at MeesPierson Derivatives in London said, "The longer these markets fail to push decisively upward and soon, the greater the chance of a retest of the lower end of the ranges to find support, as the longs are quietly withering on the vine."
"Gas oil and unleaded lead the way up so we look to them to provide this momentum (for crude) soon," she added.

However, on the fundamental side narrower crack margins for products after crude's recent run-up has caused BP and Texaco to cut runs in Rotterdam, and others to think of doing so, pressurising crude.

10 and 20-day moving averages are creeping higher and widening apart again with little sign of a directional cross but directionally 14-day RSIs continue to teeter on the edge of the 70 percent overbought line.
Momentum indicators for gas oil are also edging higher but there is little sign of a correction on the charts.

The $173 to $176.50 gap-up from last Friday to Monday remains supportively intact providing a solid base to move higher, however, MeesPierson said in their daily report that it could easily be argued that gas oil was still in an extended range, $179.50 being high and $175.25 the low.
NYMEX crude futures ended little changed Thursday after a quiet day leading up to the Memorial Day weekend, as the market continued to consolidate after last week's rally.
Crude oil for July delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange settled unchanged at $21.86 a barrel.
-- Colin Wooster, London Newsroom, +44 171 542 7456
